title: ASP.NET Core
description1: During my studies, I have coded RESTful APIs both in Java and Python. However, after spending a year with .NET at work, I doubt I will ever be returning to those two.
description2: The APIs I code today typically serve as three-layer backend applications that query the Dynamics CRM and prepare data for the frontend.
description3: When I am not writing APIs, I use .NET to code plugins and workflows that supplement the inbuilt functionalities of the CRM.

title: Vue.js
description1: A good colleague of mine first demonstrated Vue 3 to me in the last year of college. As a result, I ended up doing the frontend of my masters degree application in Vue 3.
description2: I find this framework very efficatious, especially when used with Composition API and libraries like Vite, Pinia and PrimeVue.
description3: Although these are my preference, I have also worked on applications that utilize Vue 2, Options API and Buefy. Also, this site was made using Vue 3 ðŸ˜Š

title: JS/TS
description1: College never taught me TypeScript so I wrote my masters thesis in JavaScript thinking it can't be that bad in practice... And then in Combis I got to work in a team.
description2: This is when it struck me how much more practical type safety is: it just helps you understand your teammates code faster and make less mistakes.
description3: ES6 is the way of life.

title: Version Control
description1: I am of the opinion that no activity binds teammates together better than resolving merge conflicts and restoring the stable main branch. If you haven't broken production once, you haven't lived.
description2: Jokes aside, version control is not the strongest of my suits, but I do make great efforts to follow established protocols and deploy correct versions to production.
description3: ChatGPT suggested I write "iTs aBoUt tEllInG tHe sToRy oF a pRoJeCt"... lol. Go home GPT, you're drunk.

title: Microsoft Dynamics 365
description1: In my mind, the Dynamics CRM is a fancy database manager and I like it a lot. Business logic customization is very straightforward and offers possibilities that cover most clients' needs 99% time.
description2: This of course includes writing custom plugins, scripts and webresources as well as security role management and custom document templates.
description3: All this is supplemented by the knowledge of various tools from the XrmToolBox, primarily the Plugin Trace Viewer, the Auto Number Manager and the Ribbon Workbench.

title: Microsoft Azure
description1: I havent't yet found myself in a role where I have done a lot of cloud configuration, but some projects I have worked on have required coding Azure functions.
description2: From what I have gathered, Azure is pretty essential to the CRM, so I expect to enhance my understanding of it quite soon. Stay tuned!

title: Customer Support
description1: 99% of the time, developers provide solutions for non-IT people so a bit of patience and teaching proclivity is required as a part of the job.
description2: This often reminds me of math tutoring. We assemble to solve a problem and do our best to find the easiest and most practical solution.
description3: In my experience, a dev is happiest when this role can be delegated to the business analyst; however, our technical expertise often takes us in many different directions during development.

title: Business Process Analysis
description1: Software development is a cyclical process, and every iteration naturally brings new ideas.
description2: These ideas are difficult to implement without the knowledge of underlying business processes and, in my experience, the same patterns frequently repeat across many different clients.
description3: Sometimes the client is ready to adapt to a completely new system, and sometimes the CRM is designed to emulate an already existing system. Either way, the goal is to simplify their life as much a s possible.

title: Presentation Skills
description1: I always thought my English teachers went a bit overboard with all the speaking exercises we did in school. Turns out, these skills really are invaluable in a job where interaction with clients is a daily occurence.
description2: My professional presentations typically include demonstrating new functionalities of the CRM to the client; however, I am capable of presenting any topic (both in Croatian and English) as long as I get to adequately prepare.
